Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Multiplayer vs. Single-Player iVR Training for Surgical Skills Acquisition

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised using block randomisation in a 1:1 ratio

Participants.evidence: junior orthopedic surgical residents and novice scrub technicians. Conducted at Imperial College, London

Intervention.evidence: randomised using block randomisation in a 1:1 ratio to either individual or team iVR training

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether multiplayer immersive Virtual Reality (iVR) training is superior to single-player training

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Non-Operative Technical Skills for Surgeons (NOTSS) score, evaluated by two blinded assessors.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised using block randomisation in a 1:1 ratio

Number_Randomised.evidence: 40 participants, randomised using block randomisation in a 1:1 ratio

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on all 40 participants using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Team-trained participants outperformed individually trained participants in nontechnical skills (NOTSS: 13.1±1.5 vs 10.6±1.6, P = 0.002), completed procedures 33% faster (28.2 minutes ± 5.5 vs 41.8 ± 8.9, P < 0.001), and made fewer technical errors (10.4 ± 6.1 vs 22.6 ± 5.4, P < 0.001).
